title: 104_s1486
content: PLACEMENT PROGRAMS FOR FEDERAL EMPLOYEES AFFECTED BY REDUCTION IN FORCE ACTIONS. The "Public Servant Priority Placement Act of 1995" establishes placement programs for Federal employees affected by reduction in force actions. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management must establish a Government-wide program and each agency must establish an agency program to facilitate employment placement for affected employees. The "Public Servant Priority Placement Act of 1995" requires agencies to offer vacant positions to qualified employees affected by reduction in force, with specific criteria for the offered position's classification, pay rate, and geographic location. The Government-wide placement program established under the "Public Servant Priority Placement Act of 1995" coordinates with agency programs for employee placement after a reduction in force. It requires offering vacant positions to qualified employees within the commuting area of their residence or last position, with specific criteria for classification matching. The Public Servant Priority Placement Act of 1995 establishes a Government-wide placement program that coordinates with agency programs for employee placement after a reduction in force. It requires offering vacant positions to qualified employees within the commuting area of their residence or last position, with specific criteria for classification matching. The program does not affect any priority placement program of the Department of Defense in operation before the enactment of this section. The Public Servant Priority Placement Act of 1995 establishes a Government-wide placement program for employees after a reduction in force, offering vacant positions to qualified employees within the commuting area. Technical and Conforming Amendments are made to section headings and the table of sections in chapter 33 of title 5, United States Code. Government-wide list of vacant positions and placement programs for Federal employees affected by reduction in force actions are established under the Public Servant Priority Placement Act of 1995.
